issue.title: Update kem_lima to new version
issue.body:
> On Sep 20, 2018, at 4:17 AM, Nigel Smart <nigel.paul.smart@gmail.com> wrote:
> 
> Hi
> 
> The LIMA team have updated their specification to
> a v1.1 variant available here...
> 
> https://lima-pq.github.io/
> 
> This removes the problem with the rejection sampling
> for encryption mentioned in an earlier comment. This
> has been replaced with a standard decryption error
> analysis.
> 
> The result of this is that parameter sizes for the
> power-of-two rings can be made significantly smaller.
> We have created new parameters, and the reference and
> optimized implementations now implement these.
> 
> Yours
> 
> Nigel

comment.body: Won't fix since Lima didn't make it to Round 2.

issue.title: Add Lotus
issue.body:
The Lotus implementation was MIT licensed as of mid Oct 2018, but the code needs some work before it can be added to nist-branch:
* A security patch needs to be applied for the Reference Implementation
* TODO: is the security patch required for the Optimised Implementation? If so, will the authors be providing this? (need to contact them)

Other:
* Add changes after the work to put the algorithms in alphabetic order is merged...

comment.body: Won't do since Lotus didn't make it to Round 2.

issue.title: Fixed macro ifdefs to enable building without openssl.
issue.body:
The OQS fork was not building when compiling the project without openssl:
`./configure --enable-pq-kex --enable-hybrid-kex --without-openssl --prefix=<path_to_openssh> --sysconfdir=<path_to_openssh> --with-liboqs-dir=<path_to_oqs>`

I added some ifdef macros in the OQS-related hybrid code that also needed openssl.

comment.body: oqs_openssh.sh integration tests pass on macOS.  (Admittedly, they don't exercise the problem that prompted this, but at least the change didn't break the normal case.  Do you think we should add the command-line you listed above to the integration tests to ensure no regressions?)

issue.title: Fixed macro ifdefs to enable building without openssl.
issue.body:
The OQS fork was not building when compiling the project without openssl:
`./configure --enable-pq-kex --enable-hybrid-kex --without-openssl --prefix=<path_to_openssh> --sysconfdir=<path_to_openssh> --with-liboqs-dir=<path_to_oqs>`

I added some ifdef macros in the OQS-related hybrid code that also needed openssl.

comment.body: Perhaps; I tumbled on this issue by trying to build the project without openssl because my machine didn't have an old-enough version of openssl. I'm not a 100% sure of the implications of building without openssl and if this is even recommended in a real deployment (vs. dev environment). I'll open the issue to investigate if this should be added to our integration tests.

issue.title: Initial commit of OQS .Net C# wrapper.
issue.body: Initial commit of OQS .Net C# wrapper.

comment.body: @dstebila, I'll try from a fresh VM tomorrow to see if I need to add additional installation instructions.

issue.title: Initial commit of OQS .Net C# wrapper.
issue.body: Initial commit of OQS .Net C# wrapper.

comment.body:
Ok, I tried on a fresh VM; worked for me. A few things:

- Yes, the project targets .net core 1.1; not the current 2.0 or in-preview 3.0. Moving to a newer framework removes support to older platforms; although complicates install on new machines. I'll add a note in the readme. I suggest we leave this as is, and revisit prior to our v1.0 to see which platform is preferred (based on user feedback)
- Trying to build on the command line is error-prone (if a package is missing). That's what's described in the readme, for brevity reasons, but opening the solutions (both for OQS and the wrapper) in Visual Studio provides helpful messages to resolve issue (e.g., re-target the Windows SDK to build OQS, and a bunch of missing packages were retrieved automatically for the wrapper).
- I didn't get the error you last saw, wrt the missing QOS function. This is a fairly new function in OQS; did you download a fresh copy of the library from the master branch?
- Can we change the github project name? It might be better to call this liboqs-dotnet given the generalized platform that .net is
- Speaking of, .net also works on linux and macOS, so it would be interesting to try the project there too. I'm not sure how the DllImport would work on these platforms howerver... (I'll open an investigative issue for that)

issue.title: Initial commit of OQS .Net C# wrapper.
issue.body: Initial commit of OQS .Net C# wrapper.

comment.body: @dstebila; I've pushed more details on the build (and how to potentially resolve issues).

issue.title: Refactor liboqs-python to project guidelines
issue.body:
Partial refactor: moved some files into sub dirs and renamed them. A __init__.py has been added to allow core elements to be imported from the oqs package to make namespaces simpler.

These docs are being used to guide structuring the project:
https://docs.python-guide.org/

comment.body:
> I reviewed the changes in the diff tool; looks good. I tried to run the project but the REAMDE instructions don't work anymore. Can you also modify the README to explain how to run the lib/test/sample?

Ooops, that's fixed. Users just need to set the PYTHONPATH env variable & give the right file paths.

issue.title: Initial commit of OQS .Net C# wrapper.
issue.body: Initial commit of OQS .Net C# wrapper.

comment.body:
Got it to build successfully.  Yes, my mistake was using an old version of liboqs that didn't have the new function.  

I filled out the README a bit and have merged.

I also renamed the project to liboqs-dotnet.
